descript.abstract: World Wildlife Fund Ecoregions represents global terrestrial and freshwater ecoregions defined as relatively large areas of land or water in the world that share a large majority of their species, dynamics, and environmental conditions. It contains the terrestrial habitats and some freshwater habitats of the Global 200 ecoregions, a collection of the Earth's most outstanding and diverse terrestrial, freshwater, and marine habitats--areas where the Earth's biological wealth is most distinctive and rich, where its loss will be most severely felt, and where we must fight the hardest for conservation. The data is from the World Wildlife Fund Conservation Science Program 1998 - 1999. For more information, contact http://www.worldwildlife.org.
descript.purpose: World Wildlife Fund Ecoregions provides a global view of mainly terrestrial ecoregions defined by the World Wildlife Fund Conservation Science Program 1998 - 1999, and can be used for geographic display and analysis at national and world levels.
descript.supplinf: Largest scale when displaying the data: 1:3,000,000.

idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 3; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.2.6.1500

dataqual.logic: Nine data sets were merged together to create this one shapefile and great lengths were taken to ensure no duplicate features are present, but it can't be guaranteed. The shapefile is exported using Avenue request ExportClean. This request verifies and enforces the correctness of shapes.
dataqual.complete: After processing, the data set is checked for drawing display and number of records and file sizes compared with source materials.

horizpa.horizpar: The geospatial part of this data set is based on the Digital Chart of the World (1:1,000,000 scale) that has been generalized. Generalizing reduces positional accuracy and the tolerance was not recorded so the positional accuracy is not known.

citeinfo.title: World Wildlife Fund Conservation Science Program 1998 - 1999

procstep.procdesc: The WWF Conservation Science Program 1998 - 1999 created terrestrial ecoregions for the world by continent including, Africa, Asia, Australia, Central/South America, Europe, Greenland, Hawaii, Islands, and North America.

The following steps were performed by ESRI: Extracted the continental data sets from World Wildlife Fund media. Located and removed overlapping features between less dense continents. Between dense continents, used the Clip tool of the ArcView Geoprocessing Extension to remove overlapping features. Edited each data set to contain similar attributes. Merged all continents into one data set. Calculated Mht_name attribute to "Water" for all records where Ecoregion attribute value was "Water". Fixed a typographical error in Ecoregion attribute. Increased width of Mht_name attribute to fit its longest length values. Removed attributes where values were missing or out of domain range. Recalculated attributes, where possible, to keep within domain range. Created ArcGIS� layer file (.lyr). Created ArcView legend file (.avl). Created projection file (.prj). Ran ArcView Avenue request ExportClean, and created spatial indices.

enttyp.enttypd: The polygons represent global terrestrial and freshwater ecoregions defined as relatively large areas of land or water in the world that share a large majority of their species, dynamics, and environmental conditions.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: The descriptive name for the ecoregion. Ecoregions are relatively large areas of land or water that share a large majority of their species, dynamics, and environmental conditions.
The major habitat for the area.

edom.edomvd: Deserts and xeric shrublands major habitat.
Snow, ice, glaciers, and rock major habitat.
Temperate broadleaf and mixed forests major habitat.
Temperate grasslands, savannas, and shrublands major habitat.
Tropical and subtropical coniferous forests major habitat.

edom.edomv: Tropical and subtropical dry broadleaf forests
edom.edomvd: Tropical and subtropical dry broadleaf forests major habitat.

edom.edomv: Tropical and subtropical grasslands, savannas, and shrublands
edom.edomvd: Tropical and subtropical grasslands, savannas, and shrublands major habitat.

edom.edomv: Tropical and subtropical moist broadleaf forests
edom.edomvd: Tropical and subtropical moist broadleaf forests major habitat.

attr.attrdef: The biological distinctiveness index. It is based on the species richness, endemism, rareness, etc.
The degree of threat to the ecoregion. Such threats are from logging, conversion to agriculture/urbanization, etc.

edom.edomvd: Relatively stable in degree of threat.
Relatively intact in degree of threat.

attr.attrdef: The final assessment of the ecoregion as the estimated threat to the ecoregion over the next 20 years.

edom.edomvd: Critical in estimated threat over the next 20 years.
Endangered in estimated threat over the next 20 years.
Vulnerable in estimated threat over the next 20 years.
Relatively stable in estimated threat over the next 20 years.
Relatively intact in estimated threat over the next 20 years.

cntorgp.cntorg: Digital Social Science Center (DSSC), Columbia University Libraries
